Dear Sheffield City Council,
I am writing to you under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 to request the following information:
1. The number of your current job descriptions that include the use of "AI/artificial intelligence" as a skill, requirement, or desirable attribute.
2. Details about how your organisation is currently utilising artificial intelligence. Specifically, I am interested in the projects or tasks where AI is employed.
3. Information regarding whether there is a dedicated team within your organisation focused on the implementation or management of AI technologies.
3. Any available information on planned future uses of AI within your organisation.
Yours faithfully,
Laura Riley

Dear Laura Riley,
Thank you for your request for information relating to AI in organisation
which we received on 28/06/2023.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1. The number of your current job descriptions that include the use of
"AI/artificial intelligence" as a skill, requirement, or desirable
attribute.
Sheffield City Council currently have no job descriptions that list
Artificial Intelligence (AI) as a skill, requirement or desirable
attribute. We are in the process of developing two new job descriptions
that will reference AI, but these have not yet gone through internal
review processes. These roles are Automation Lead and Enterprise
Architect.
2. Details about how your organisation is currently utilising artificial
intelligence. Specifically, I am interested in the projects or tasks
where AI is employed.
Sheffield City Council currently uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) for a
limited range of tasks predominantly relating to image recognition. This
includes automatic number plate recognition for managing bus lanes and the
Clean Air Zone. We have also recently started a test for change with
willing social care users, which involves the use of Internet of Things
(IoT) sensors by our partners. The data from these sensors is amalgamated
and analysed using AI to help identify where a proactive and preventative
health or social care intervention may be required such as in the
prevention of falls.
We do have access to corporate AI technology in the form of ‘AI Builder’,
which is part of Microsoft’s Power Platform. We are not currently using AI
Builder for any ‘live’ tasks, projects or processes, it has only been used
in development environments to help us better understand the capabilities
of the technology. We have implemented the Power Platform Centre of
Excellence suite to enable us to monitor and control any use of this AI
tool.
However, we acknowledge that there are open AI technologies (like ChatGPT)
that employees are experimenting with, that are more difficult to monitor
how they are used. We do not believe that open AI is being used in any
formal tasks or projects, but are seeking to ensure appropriate oversight
and governance is in place through the development of a Responsible AI
Policy.
3. Information regarding whether there is a dedicated team within your
organisation focused on the implementation or management of AI
technologies.
Any AI technologies will be implemented and managed by the ICT & Digital
Innovation Service, working in collaboration with other services. The
Technical Design Authority (TDA) will also review AI technologies before
they are implemented.
4. Any available information on planned future uses of AI within your
organisation.
We are currently developing a Responsible AI Policy that will define how
AI can be used ethically, responsibly and safely with Sheffield City
Council. We will also develop a Digital Strategy that outlines a roadmap
for how AI could provide better customer experience and operational
efficiencies. Areas of potential exploration may include document reading
(such as invoices), IoT and chatbots.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
